data.title: Conflict: a Distributed Condition: Contemporary War Ecologies
data.desc:
Conflict is not an exception or an isolated event — it is a constant condition running through society. It is not limited to war or explicit clashes: it emerges within collective life as friction, as a continuous confrontation between competing needs, systems, and visions.
It is not a punctual episode but a latent and distributed condition. It takes on asymmetric, often invisible forms, embedded in cultural practices, social relations, and infrastructures. Its logic is not confined to violence: it also structures coexistence, shaping who holds privilege and who is pushed to the margins.
Exploring distributed conflicts means reading the present as a field where techniques of offense multiply and blur into the infrastructures society depends on. The goal is to generate critical devices, scenarios, and questions that probe the ambiguous nature of conflict as a diffuse condition in a post-territorial age.

data.title: Definition of Conflict
data.desc:
Positive: costitutive condition of living together. It's the result of the human plurality. It could be positive confront, structural antagonism that moves history. 

Negative: conflict as a consequence of power-resistance dynamics, and as the base of institutions.
links: Jean-Luc Nancy, Hanna Arendt, Marx, Nietzche, Foucault

data.title: Definition of Infrastructure
data.desc: Complementary works necessary for the performance of an activity (roads, railways, aqueducts, telecommunication networks, digital). They are the foundation of the main structure, necessary for the economic and social development of a country.

data.title: Physical Infrastructures
data.desc: Material and tangible components necessary for the functioning of society and the economy, including transportation systems (roads, railways, ports), essential services (energy, water, telecommunications), buildings, and, in the IT sector, data centers, servers, and networking equipment.

data.title: Technological and Digital Infrastructures
data.desc: The set of hardware, software, networks, and data centers that enable the management of digital data and resources, supporting the daily activities and growth strategies of organizations and society. Key elements include data centers, storage systems, networking equipment (routers and switches), cloud platforms, and data processing systems, making connectivity, security, and efficiency of digital processes possible.

data.title: Social Infrastructures
data.desc: The set of assets functional to meeting essential collective needs, particularly in the areas of education, healthcare, and housing.

data.title: Law & Order and Institutional Infrastructures
data.desc: Law & Order infrastructure refers to the systems, institutions, and resources that uphold public safety, enforce laws, and guarantee justice. It includes courts, police, prisons, and regulatory bodies, ensuring stability and protection of rights.

data.title: Economical and financial Infrastructures
data.desc: Economic and financial infrastructure refers to the set of institutions, markets, and systems that enable the functioning of the economy. It includes banks, stock exchanges, payment systems, insurance, and credit networks. These ensure the circulation of money, investment management, and the stability of transactions. Their efficiency is crucial for a country’s development and growth.

data.title: Cultural Infrastructures
data.desc: The set of material and immaterial elements (structures, spaces, technologies, communities, traditions, collections) that make up a territory’s cultural heritage and facilitate its enjoyment, development, and preservation, while promoting creativity and local identity.

data.title: Infrastructural conflict
data.desc: situation of contrast, opposition, and tension, that regards the project, localisation, realisation, management, resignation of an infrastructure (physical or immaterial).

data.desc:

data.title: Biopower
data.desc: Whereas power was once exercised explicitly and performatively (public executions and torture) and manifested in decisions of life or death, today power is directed toward life itself, specifically its control. Infrastructure plays a fundamental role in this.

data.title: Urbicide
data.desc: "Urbicide” is the deliberate destruction of a city or urban environment, targeting its infrastructure, buildings, and social fabric, often to erase its cultural identity or to weaken the community living there.

data.title: War Necropolitics
data.desc: The infrastructure needed to face a war is not accessible to the entire society. It may be necessary to choose who can be saved and who cannot.

data.title: Necropolitics
data.desc: Necropolitics is a concept by the Cameroonian philosopher Achille Mbembe that describes how political power controls people not only through life (biopolitics) but especially through death, determining who lives and who must die.

data.title: The white man's burden
data.desc: A poem by Kipling in which he describes the “duty” of the European man, presenting the construction of infrastructure as a “colonial aid” for “inferior” peoples, which in reality translates into cultural and social domination.

data.title: War targets riorganized for a socio-economical advantage
Energetic Infrastructures
data.desc: Energy infrastructure refers to the systems, facilities, and equipment needed to generate, transmit, store, and distribute energy. These networks keep our homes warm, our factories running, and our cities moving.

data.title: Power Grids
data.desc: Power grid is an infrastructure system that generates, transmits, and distributes electricity from power plants to homes, businesses, and industries. It ensures that electrical energy produced at power stations—such as those using fossil fuels, nuclear power, or renewable sources like wind and solar—can travel long distances and reach consumers safely and reliably.

data.title: Sattelits
data.desc: Satellites like Starlink play a crucial role in warfare, providing Internet access in areas without terrestrial infrastructure. In Ukraine, they support military communications, drone control, and real-time data transmission. They enable operational coordination even in active conflict zones, becoming essential on the battlefield. However, they raise geopolitical and security concerns related to the use of private technology in wars.

data.title: Transportation
data.desc: Transportation infrastructure is the physical network that enables the movement of people and goods, including roads, railways, airports, and canals. It is crucial for economic growth, trade, and social well-being, requiring significant investment and planning to ensure safe, efficient, and sustainable systems.

data.title: In Italy
data.desc: Italy has a well-developed transportation infrastructure with extensive networks of highways and railways, including an operational high-speed rail system that ranks among the longest in the world. The country plays a strategic role in the TEN-T Core Network for the EU market, hosting several European Corridors that connect key industrial clusters, ports, and airports.

data.title: Integration of travel in more facets of life
Environmental sustainability vs developement
data.desc: A socio-political and ecological conflict arises when an infrastructure generates severe environmental impacts or redistributes resources in ways that harm ecosystems and livelihoods, while being presented as a driver of development. The conflict stems from the unequal distribution of costs and benefits and from inadequate decision-making processes and remedies.

data.title: Humanitary/Sanitary help vs war target
data.desc: Hospitals, clinics, ambulances, aid distribution centers, and civilian shelters are attacked or threatened during armed conflicts, despite being designed to protect and save lives.

data.title: Instruction palce vs distruction place
data.desc: Between 2022 and 2023, there were approximately 6,000 attacks on schools and universities worldwide, affecting over 10,000 students and teachers, mainly in Palestine, Ukraine, and the DRC. The attacks, including bombings, arson, and military use of schools, caused prolonged closures, loss of months of education, and severe psychological effects. HRW urges states to adopt the Safe Schools Declaration to protect education during conflicts.

data.title: Turism vs Welfare
data.desc: The way the new forms of overtourism are undermining the welfare of local populations

data.title: La città del sole
data.desc: “La città del Sole” (1602) by Tommaso Campanella is a utopian dialogue that describes an ideal society organized in concentric circles, governed by a priest-philosopher called Sun and his magistrates. In it, there is no private property; everything is shared, even families and children. Education is collective and based on symbols and knowledge painted on the city’s walls. It is a model of harmony between religion, science, and politics, set against the injustices of its time.

data.title: Neuroarchitecture
data.desc: Neuroarchitecture is an interdisciplinary field that combines architecture, neuroscience, psychology, and ergonomics to study how built environments influence the brain, emotions, and human behavior.

data.title: Foreigners everywhere: Biennale
data.desc: Foreigners Everywhere, curated by Brazilian Adriano Pedrosa, was the main art exhibition of the 60th Venice Biennale, which took place from April 20–November 24, 2024. Pedrosa's stated intention for the exhibit was to investigate the idea of living on the margins, whether as an outsider, a new arrival, or an Indigenous person.

data.title: Touristification
data.desc: Touristification is the process by which a city or area becomes dominated by tourism. It often transforms local spaces, services, and culture to cater to visitors. This can lead to economic benefits but also social tensions, displacement, and loss of local identity.

data.title: Luxury tourism
data.desc: Luxury tourism (luxury travel) is a segment of the tourism industry dedicated to travelers seeking unique, personalized, and top-level experiences, prioritizing quality, exclusivity, comfort, privacy, and personal fulfillment.

data.title: Extreme turism
data.desc: Forms of tourism practiced in remote, dangerous contexts beyond the jurisdiction of States, such as the deep sea, polar regions, or outer space.

data.title: Overtourism in Venice
data.desc: The entire physical structure of the city, from its foundations to its canals, is unable to withstand the weight of mass tourism, transforming infrastructure from a resource for residents into a source of conflict.

data.title: Jeff Bezos wedding
data.desc: Jeff Bezos’s wedding in Venice drew huge media attention and an exceptional influx of luxury guests. This kind of event amplifies the problems of elite and mass tourism, which already weigh heavily on the city. Residents experienced mobility issues, with difficult travel and restricted access. Venice thus risks becoming a global stage rather than a livable city for its inhabitants.

data.title: Spacial torusim
data.desc: Blue Origin organizes suborbital tourist flights lasting about 11 minutes, reaching altitudes over 100 km. Passengers experience a few minutes of weightlessness while observing the Earth’s curvature through large panoramic windows. The capsule then returns to Earth with a controlled parachute landing. These missions represent an exclusive form of space tourism, reserved for a select few participants.

data.title: Submarine tourism
data.desc: OceanGate organizes private submarine expeditions to the Titanic wreck, offering participants an exclusive experience aboard the Titan submersible. These missions, lasting about 10 days, cost $250,000 per person, excluding travel expenses to the departure point in Newfoundland, Canada. The business model involved passengers, called “citizen scientists,” participating in scientific research missions, but the company faced criticism over safety and operational transparency. After the fatal Titan incident in June 2023, OceanGate suspended all operations and ceased activities.

data.title: Everest Mount
data.desc: In recent years, extreme tourism on Mount Everest has surged, with thousands of climbers visiting each season. This has caused severe overcrowding, long queues to reach the summit, and increased safety risks. The Nepalese government has responded by raising permit fees and limiting the number of climbers to manage environmental and logistical impacts.

data.title: Politics of infrastructure
data.desc: Social, cultural, and political conflict can arise as early as the planning phase of an infrastructure project. Economic interests, community rights, and cultural heritage may come into conflict. The lack of dialogue fuels protests and delays, while construction often disregards human rights and local cultures.

data.title: Messina Strait Bridge
data.desc: Location: Strait of Messina (Sicily–Calabria, Italy). The project involves national governments, local administrations, construction consortia, environmental groups, and citizens, with disputes over real costs, seismic risks, and potential mafia influence. It has been repeatedly launched, suspended, and restarted. The debate remains constant, balancing promises of development against environmental, technical, and economic concerns.

data.title: No Tav
data.desc: The No TAV movement emerged in Val di Susa against the construction of the Turin–Lyon high-speed rail line. It brings together residents, activists, and social groups denouncing environmental, economic, and social impacts. Conflict with the government and law enforcement has led to protests, clashes, and legal proceedings. It has become a national symbol of resistance against top-down large-scale projects.

data.title: ZAD of Notre Dame des Landes
data.desc: In Notre-Dame-des-Landes, near Nantes, France, local farmers, ZAD ecological activists, the government, and the airport industry clashed over a new airport. Legal questions about occupations versus the right to protest fueled tensions. After decades of mobilization and resistance, strong opposition led to the airport’s cancellation in 2018. The case stands as a notable victory for social movements.

data.title: Vajont Dam
data.desc: Vajont Dam. Date: Catastrophe, October 9, 1963 (Vajont disaster). Location: Erto e Casso / Longarone, Veneto, Italy. Actors: SADE/ENEL and planners, state/regional administrations, local populations; historical ambiguity regarding responsibility and technical omissions (later confirmed by trials). Introduction: During the filling of the reservoir, a gigantic landslide generated a wave that swept away the valleys below, causing nearly 2,000 deaths; a paradigmatic episode of geological underestimation and technocratic decisions without dialogue.

data.title: Dakota Access Pipeline
data.desc: Dakota Access Pipeline (No DAPL / Standing Rock) Date: Main protests April 2016 – February 2017 (but broader impact). Location: North Dakota / routed through multiple US states. Actors: Standing Rock Sioux Tribe and other Native tribes, environmental activists, Energy Transfer Partners (proposer), federal government and agencies (Army Corps); ambiguity regarding consultations and respect for historic treaties. Introduction: Global mobilization against pipeline construction near sacred sites and water sources; symbolic episode of the assertion of indigenous rights against energy infrastructure.

data.title: Narita Airport
data.desc: Narita Airport (Sanrizuka struggle, Japan) Date: Conflict from 1966; construction and opening in 1978 (but protests continued). Location: Sanrizuka/Chiba, near Tokyo, Japan. Actors: Farmers and local residents (Sanrizuka), student and leftist groups, Japanese government and police, Narita International Airport Corporation; ambiguity regarding the radicalization of the protests and violence. Introduction: Extremely violent opposition by farmers and leftist groups against expropriations and lack of consultation: occupations, clashes, extreme acts, and years of instability during construction.

data.title: Three Gorges Dam
data.desc: Three Gorges Dam. Date: Main construction 1994–2006; turbines fully operational until 2012. Location: Yangtze, Sandouping (Hubei), China. Stakeholders: Chinese government/China Three Gorges Corp., displaced local populations, environmentalists, scientific community; ambiguity surrounding precise displacement estimates and long-term impacts. Introduction: The world's largest hydroelectric power plant by installed capacity; it has provided flood control and power, but also the displacement of over a million people and the loss of cultural/environmental sites.

data.title: Standard Gauge Railway
data.desc: Standard Gauge Railway (Kenya, Mombasa–Nairobi SGR) Date: Construction and commissioning 2013–2017 (first phase completed 2017). Location: Kenya (Mombasa–Nairobi and branches). Stakeholders: Kenyan government, Chinese companies (CPC/CRBC), port operators, local communities, environmentalists; ambiguity regarding government-to-government contractual terms, debt, and environmental impacts (including on parks). Introduction: Modern line intended to connect the port and the capital; has raised concerns regarding expropriation, land use, impacts on wildlife, and financial sustainability.

data.title: Turkish Dams (GAP and Ilısu)
data.desc: Turkish Dams on the Tigris and Euphrates (GAP/Ilısu - Hasankeyf Projects) Date: GAP project launched in the 1970s; Ilısu and related works active 2006–2020 (impoundment 2019–2020). Location: Southeast Turkey (Turkish Kurdistan), Tigris and Euphrates basins; submerged ancient city of Hasankeyf. Stakeholders: Turkish government (energy and irrigation projects), Kurdish and local communities, archaeologists/international NGOs; ambiguity regarding the balance between water/energy security and heritage protection. Introduction: Part of a broad regional development program (GAP) that has led to expropriations, forced displacement, and the loss of millennia-old sites (Hasankeyf), sparking national and international protests.

data.title: Pan-American Highway / Darien Gap
data.desc: Pan-American Highway / Darien Gap. Data: Road system development began in the 20th century; the Darien Gap remains incomplete (historical strategic absence). Location: From the Americas—a natural gap in the Darién (Panama-Colombia). Stakeholders: National governments, local indigenous communities, environmentalists; ambiguity between commercial connectivity and ecological/indigenous protection interests. Introduction: The decision not to cross the Darién—for technical, environmental, and indigenous protection reasons—has preserved an ecological barrier; it is an example of “missing infrastructure” driven by conflicts and evaluations.

data.title: Narmada Dam and Narmada Bachao Andolan
data.desc: Narmada Dam and Narmada Bachao Andolan (India) Date: Decision-making process and construction from 1960–2000; significant mobilizations from 1985 onwards. Location: Narmada River basin (states of Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat, Maharashtra), India. Actors: State and central governments, World Bank at some stages, movements led by Medha Patkar/Baba Amte, tribal and peasant communities; ambiguity regarding displacement figures and compensation arrangements. Introduction: A series of large dams (including Sardar Sarovar) that sparked one of India's best-known social resistance movements, echoing issues of development versus indigenous rights.

data.title: Israel–Palestine Separation Wall (West Bank Barrier)
data.desc: Israel–Palestine Separation Wall (West Bank Barrier) Date: Construction began in the early 2000s (after 2002); development and continuous sections. Location: Occupied West Bank territory / de facto borders. Actors: Israeli government, Palestinian authorities and Palestinian populations, international community/NGOs; ambiguity over security rationale vs. impact on rights and political future. Introduction: Barrier defended by Israel as a security measure; denounced by numerous international institutions as a tool that limits freedom of movement and de facto annexes territory.

data.title: Belo Monte Dam
data.desc: Belo Monte Dam (Brazil). Date: Ten-year project phases (since the 1970s); construction intensified in the 2000s; partially operational since 2016. Location: Xingu River, Pará, Amazon, Brazil. Stakeholders: Brazilian government, energy companies, indigenous peoples and local rebels, environmental NGOs; ambiguity regarding the number of displaced people and energy balance vs. ecological impacts. Introduction: One of the most contested hydroelectric projects in the Amazon: large submerged areas, displacement of indigenous communities, and international legal and political battles.

data.title: “Tren (or Tren) Maya” Railway Project
data.desc: “Tren (or Tren) Maya” Railway Project (Mexico). Date: Planning and construction start 2018–2023; sections partially opened/operational from 2023. Location: Yucatán Peninsula (states: Quintana Roo, Yucatán, Campeche, Tabasco, Chiapas). Stakeholders: Mexican government (AMLO), construction companies, indigenous Mayan communities, environmentalists, scientists/UNESCO; ambiguity regarding effective consultation and damage to biospheres/karst cavities. Introduction: A major tourism and regional development project that has sparked protests over environmental impacts, expropriation, and the failure to protect archaeological sites and local communities.

data.title: HS2 High-Speed ​​Rail
data.desc: HS2 High-Speed ​​Rail (UK). Date: Project approved in the 2010s; intense construction and protests, especially from 2017–2024 (and beyond). Location: Great Britain (London → Midlands → North). Actors: UK government, construction companies, local communities and environmental groups (tree activists, anti-HS2 camps), local authorities; ambiguity over economic benefits vs. destruction of forests/landscapes. Introduction: Project intended to connect regions and “balance” the country; has met with strong opposition due to its impact on ancient forests, costs, and long-term benefits.

data.title: Montalto di Castro Nuclear Power Plant
data.desc: Montalto di Castro Nuclear Power Plant (Italy). Date: Construction began 1982; halted after 1987 referendum (Chernobyl → political decision) — never entered into operation. Location: Montalto di Castro, Lazio, Italy. Actors: ENEL (proponent), government, anti-nuclear movements, public opinion (referendum); ambiguity over economic losses vs. post-Chernobyl democratic choice. Introduction: Nearing completion, the plant was halted by the national referendum that ended Italy's nuclear expansion in the 1980s; an exemplary case of direct democracy blocking an infrastructure.

data.title: Suez Canal
data.desc: Suez Canal (19th century). Date: Construction 1859–1869; inauguration November 17, 1869. Location: Isthmus of Suez, Egypt. Actors: European companies (Ferdinand de Lesseps / Compagnie universelle du canal), Egyptian authorities (viceroy), local forced laborers (corvée), colonial powers; historical ambiguity regarding actual deaths and working conditions (estimates vary). Introduction: A work that revolutionized global maritime trade; built with strong European intervention and the use of massive labor, sources differ on human losses and social cost.

data.title: Aswan High Dam
data.desc: Aswan High Dam (Egypt). Date: Construction 1960–1970 (completion 1970; filling and operation until the 1970s). Location: Aswan, Egypt (Nile). Actors: Egyptian government (Nasser), Soviet Union (support/funding), displaced Nubian populations, scientific communities, and UNESCO (Abu Simbel rescue); ambiguity over economic benefits vs. cultural loss and environmental impacts. Introduction: A national project symbolizing modernization (power and flood control) that solved many water issues but resulted in the relocation of tens of thousands of Nubians and the submergence of historic sites (international archaeological rescues).

data.title: Atatürk Airport / New Istanbul Airport (Turkey).
data.desc: Atatürk Airport / New Istanbul Airport (Turkey). Date: New airport project started 2010s; opening and relocation 2018; protests documented primarily 2017–2018. Location: Istanbul, Turkey. Actors: Turkish government (major state project), construction companies, workers (complaints about conditions), unions, and NGOs; ambiguity about actual number of accidents/deaths and transparency. Introduction: The new airport has become a symbol of modernization but also of human costs (rapid working conditions, reported fatalities) and deforestation.

data.title: Trans-Amazonian Highway (BR-230, Brazil)
data.desc: Trans-Amazonian Highway (BR-230, Brazil). Date: Construction early 1970s (military regime), subsequent expansions; incomplete and amplifying deforestation. Location: Brazilian Amazon (various portions of BR-230). Actors: Brazilian military government, settlers, agribusiness/mining companies, indigenous peoples, environmentalists; ambiguity between development slogans and actual environmental impacts. Introduction: Colonial initiative to open up the Amazon that fueled waves of deforestation, settlements, and conflicts with indigenous peoples; symbol of an infrastructure that transformed the territory.

data.title: Guatemala Highway Corridor (CA-9 and related projects)
data.desc: Guatemala Highway Corridor (CA-9 and related projects). Date: Various projects and construction over the past decades; recurring tensions (blockades and protests, especially 2010s–2020s). Location: Guatemala (port-inland connections). Actors: Guatemalan government, infrastructure companies, indigenous communities (Maya), social movements and land defense; ambiguity regarding consultation and respect for collective rights. Introduction: Connectivity projects often cross indigenous territories without adequate consultation: communities have organized blockades, assemblies, and protests to demand the right to consultation and land.

data.title: San Vittore Prison
data.desc:
Infrastructure= prisons, facilities for managing social issues

Conflict = the infrastructure itself is the conflict (often invisible, prisons are located in hidden locations; it is a mirror of a dysfunctional society, which few, however, want to address).

Structural failure: social structure that, rather than managing the problem, becomes a catalyst for crisis (overcrowding at 247%, the facility can no longer guarantee humane living conditions).

Isolation: lack of human resources to support the maintenance and health of inmates + lack of bureaucracy

data.title: Pruitt-Igoe residential complex
data.desc:
The Pruitt–Igoe complex was a massive public housing project in St. Louis, Missouri, designed by architect Minoru Yamasaki and completed in 1955. It consisted of 33 eleven-story high-rise buildings with nearly 3,000 apartments, intended to provide modern, affordable housing for low-income residents after World War II.

Initially celebrated as a symbol of urban renewal, Pruitt–Igoe soon faced serious problems, including poor maintenance, crime, poverty, and social isolation, worsened by inadequate funding and flawed design. By the late 1960s, many units were abandoned, and the complex became a national example of failed public housing policy. Beginning in 1972, the buildings were systematically demolished, marking one of the most famous collapses of modernist architecture and urban planning ideals in the United States.

data.title: Hulme Crescents Notorious residential complex
data.desc:
The Hulme Crescents were a vast public housing development in Manchester, England, completed in 1972 as part of a postwar urban renewal plan. Consisting of four massive curved concrete blocks with deck-access walkways, they were intended to provide modern, affordable homes inspired by the elegance of Georgian architecture.

Despite their ambitious design, the Crescents quickly suffered from poor construction, damp, heating problems, and rising crime, while their elevated walkways created isolation and safety concerns. Within just a few years many residents demanded rehousing, and the complex gained a reputation for neglect and danger. By the early 1990s the buildings were largely abandoned, and between 1993 and 1995 the entire development was demolished, becoming a symbol of failed modernist housing policy in the UK.

data.title: Common critical point in infrastructural projects
data.desc:
FUNCTION – Expression of intent by individuals or authorities that can create conflicts of interest within society.

PLANNING – Organizational problems, such as the urgent need for a facility that cannot be built in time.

DESIGN – Architectural choices that clash with the intended function, for example buildings poorly suited to their environment or use.

CONSTRUCTION – Environmental and social issues related to the location or size of the infrastructure.

USE – A gap between the project’s concept and its realization, leaving users dissatisfied.

DEGRADATION – Abandonment and disuse of infrastructures, leading to wasted resources.

data.title: Grenfell Tower (London, 2017)
data.desc:
Grenfell Tower (London, 2017)

Problem: Fire caused by combustible cladding, resulting in 72 deaths.

Psychological effects: Survivors and residents of nearby blocks reported post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), anxiety, insomnia, and fire-related phobias.

Legal relevance: The UK government recognized the need for long-term psychological support for former residents.

data.title: Citicorp Center (New York, 1970s)
data.desc:
Citicorp Center (New York, 1970s)

Problem: It was discovered that the building could collapse in the event of strong winds.

Psychological effects: When the news became public, tenants reported chronic anxiety and fear of working on the upper floors—even after repairs.

data.title: John Hancock Tower (Boston, 1970s)
data.desc:
John Hancock Tower (Boston, 1970s)

Problem: Glass panels detached and fell.

Psychological effects: Workers and passersby spoke of “constant terror” and “killer glass panic,” and many avoided walking beneath the building.

data.title: Infrastructural limits
data.desc:
Infrastructure becomes a means and place for bureaucratic decisions

Like
Accessibility to hospitals
Accessibility to bunkers
Accessibility to prisons

data.title: Infrastructures that feed social conflict
data.desc:
Infrastructure, depending on how and where it is built, can create or accentuate social conflict by increasing social isolation, discrimination, poverty, and crime.
This phenomenon often occurs with spatial renewal policies, such as those in Scampia, Pruitt-Igoe, and Hulme Crescents

data.title: Infrastructures that increase war conflict
data.desc:
These are infrastructures that are built specifically for war or infrastructures that, if manipulated, can be used as a weapon fueling conflict.
Such as
Trade routes (e.g., the Silk Road, tariffs, etc.)
Gas in Russia
Tariffs as an economic logistics infrastructure
Arms trafficking fuels wars
Soldier transportation
Food transportation

data.title: Grim milestone on World Humanitarian Day
data.desc:
WHO records 1940 attacks on healthcare in Ukraine since the start of full-scale war.
→ Systematic data on attacks on healthcare facilities, their impact on primary and secondary services, and consequences for patients and medical staff. Useful for documenting the phenomenon of healthcare attacks as a war strategy/effect.

data.title: Russian attacks on Ukraine power grid
data.desc:
Russian attacks on Ukraine power grid likely violate humanitarian law, says UN
→ The UN has declared that repeated Russian attacks on Ukraine's power grid between March and August 2024 likely violate international humanitarian law. The attacks on energy infrastructure have left entire cities without power, compromising water, heating, and essential services. Blackouts of up to 18 hours a day are expected. Kiev and its allies consider them war crimes, while Moscow maintains they are legitimate military targets.

data.title: EU: Russian gas phase-out, end of imports by 2027
data.desc:
→ The EU wants to reduce dependence on Russian gas: starting in 2026, a halt to new contracts and the use of LNG terminals for Russian customers, and from 2028, long-term contracts. Each country will have to plan alternatives to avoid energy crises. But the construction of new infrastructure creates tensions: local protests, conflicts between states, and a clash between energy security and ecological transition.

Gas pipelines such as Nord Stream 1 and 2 have made Europe dependent on Russian supplies for approximately 40% of its gas needs, giving Russia bargaining and political power over it.

data.title: Yemen's water situation
data.desc: Yemen faces a severe water crisis: war, poor infrastructure, and excessive consumption for qat cultivation have drastically reduced access to drinking water. The lack of safe water has led to epidemics, such as cholera. The ICRC is responding by repairing wells and water networks, distributing water and treatment supplies, and supporting millions of people each year.

data.title: Conflict Resilience of Water and Energy Supply Infrastructure: Insights from Yemen
data.desc: → Examines the resilience of water and energy infrastructure in Yemen during the armed conflict that began in 2015. It analyzes the adaptive responses of communities and public institutions to disruptions and shortages in the water and energy sectors, critically assessing these responses from the perspective of infrastructure resilience in conflict contexts.

data.title: WHAT IF YOUR BIOLOGICAL PARAMETERS REGULATED ACCESS TO INFRASTRUCTURES LIKE SUBWAY?
data.desc:
How spaces influence us. 

Conflict: inadequacy of the infrastructure system that deals with safety, inner emotional
Causes: possibility of access to an infrastructure
Implications: homologation and emotional flattening, greater security

Agents: infrastructure and people

How the conflict develops: is it legitimate to experience a certain emotional state?
Imagine wanting to take the subway to go dancing: if the infrastructure detects that you're too drunk, stressed, or irritated, you're denied access until your biometric and emotional parameters fall within the permitted threshold. Infrastructure thus becomes active emotional filters, forcing individuals to modulate their internal state in order to use public spaces.

Sccenario: ATM, the public transport company, aims to optimize operational efficiency by reducing delays caused by accidents, vandalism, or violent incidents, in order to ensure high levels of safety and service reliability.
In the near future, the growing need to integrate and connect an ever-increasing number of areas of the city of Milan, benefiting both residents and tourists of all ages, will require innovative solutions.
ATM intends to distinguish itself from other transport operators by introducing strategies and technologies capable of optimizing passenger flow management, improving safety, and reducing operational disruptions, positioning itself as a benchmark service in urban mobility.

data.title: WHAT IF THE INFRASTRUCTURES SURROUNDING YOU MONITORED YOU 24/7?
data.desc:
Compliance architecture

Conflict: they intervene in your emotional and social sphere, shaping your moral choices and individual expressions
Causes: monitors become behavioral and emotional control system
Implications: society of facades and exclusion


Agents: infrastructures and people

How the conflict develops: 
- Infrastructure that captures => smart walls or pavements, radar sensors that detect heartbeats, networks that capture personal data, etc.

- Infrastructure that imposes judgment => decides that the stressed person is a risk to optimization and must be isolated.

The core of the conflict isn't limited to the physical infrastructure (from bricks and mortar to buildings), but rather the entire series of dynamics that are part of the logistics of an infrastructure, from bureaucracy, administrative organization, economic agreements...
Infrastructure therefore has the power to influence the lives of individuals, from the way cities, neighborhoods, homes, public and private buildings, to places of education, etc., are organized.

Scenario:
→ School: A child with high levels of stress/attention is isolated or sent to "corrective" courses that limit their interaction with the rest of the community.

→ Office: Meetings are judged not only on output, but also on the "level of emotional engagement," penalizing those who...

→ Transportation: The car won't start if your stress/sleep levels are too high,
or on the bus, the system identifies the "visibly agitated" person and sends an alarm.

→ Home: There is no longer a private space in which to be "imperfect" or "simply tired." Monitoring is total and pervasive.


If our authenticity were the price we paid for an “optimized” and integrated life, how willing would we be to do it?

data.title: WHAT IF A SWIPE DECIDED WHO ENTERED THE CITY? WHAT IF RESIDENTS HAD THE RIGHT TO VOTE ON TOURIST ENTRY IN REAL TIME?
data.desc:
What we want to consider: 
- Infrastructure is inadequate for the number of people who want to access it
- Overtourism and difficulties in life for residents of highly visited cities

Conflict: the ever-increasing presence of tourists in excessive numbers makes essential services inaccessible to residents (e.g. Venice and its streets, means of transport).
Causes: the city is not large enough and equipped to continue to accommodate ever-increasing flows of tourists.
Implications: tensions among residents towards tourists

Agents: tourists, residents, streets

How the conflict develops: Venice has implemented a regulated access system to manage tourist flow and protect the city from overcrowding. Each day, the number of visitors allowed is limited, and entry is not automatic: tourists must go through a selection process managed by residents.
Non-residents interested in visiting the city must create a digital profile on a dedicated app, carefully curating their virtual image. This profile acts as an entry ticket: the more interesting or attractive the tourist appears according to established social criteria, the greater the chances of being chosen.
Each resident has the daily task of selecting a certain number of tourists to admit. Visitors with the most votes receive special privileges, such as exclusive access to events, discounts, or unique experiences.
The system introduces a unique dynamic: tourists themselves become attractions. As they pass by, other visitors and residents can leave reviews and ratings, creating a sort of public reputation and influencing future selections. Cities, meanwhile, compete with each other to attract the "most desirable" tourists, transforming the tourist experience into a global juggling act. for example tourists must have certain characteristics to access

data.title: Turistification

Global metropolises face a dilemma: their economic growth increasingly depends on tourism and external investment, but this development often conflicts with the needs of locals. On the one hand, tourists and mobile workers are a vital source of income, willing to spend on services that meet their needs. On the other, residents see their cities transforming and losing their identity. This creates a growing tension between those who experience the city daily and those who use it as an "amusement park" or investment capital.

data.title: Infrastructure policies
data.desc:
Social, cultural, and political conflict can arise as early as the planning stage of infrastructure. Cases like Vajont, the Standard Gauge Railway in Kenya, the No TAV movement, and the bridge over the Strait of Messina demonstrate how economic interests, community rights, and cultural heritage can collide. Lack of dialogue fuels protests and delays, while construction often ignores human rights and local cultures. If protests themselves defined the value of infrastructure, how would we measure progress? Would the culture of dissent become the fundamental infrastructure for protecting our cultural heritage?

Problem:
- Non-transparent procedures
- Human rights violations
- Loss of cultural heritage

Agents:
- Minor populations
- Civilians
- Investors

Infrastructures:
- Dams
- Railway networks
- Hydroelectric power plants

Scenarios:
- Reality

- Migration
- Uprooting

data.title: LAND GRABBING
data.desc:
OUR DEFINITION OF LANDGRABBING:
Land grabbing refers to the buying and selling of land often in developing countries that is considered to be unused despite the many locals who live there. This ruthless action displaces these small communities leaving them with nothing and no where to go. Now considered the modern form of colonization, Land Grabbing is one of the most important topics in human rights and environmental law. Land Grabbing benefits governments and large multinational companies at the expense of peoples livelihoods.

data.title: 2023 LAND GRABBING REPORT- FOCSIV
data.desc:
LAND INVESTMENTS AROUND THE WORLD:
The chart shows the distribution of agreements concluded by geographic area in millions of hectares, totaling 114.8 million hectares. Africa is the leading continent for investments that can lead to land grabbing to the detriment of local communities, followed by Latin America, Eastern Europe, and then Asia. The distribution by investment intention is broken down as follows: 40% for forestry, 33% for other purposes, particularly mining, and 26% for agriculture. 67% of the area covered by agreements has ongoing operations, 25% is in the start-up phase, 5% of the area has operations abandoned, and 3% has not yet started. (image 1)

INVESTOR COUNTRIES AND TARGETS OF LAND GRABBING:
The chart illustrates the top 10 countries with concluded and unconcluded agreements, expressed in millions of hectares. It shows that the Russian Federation is by far the country receiving the most foreign land investments, followed by Peru (especially for mining) and the Democratic Republic of the Congo (for agricultural monocultures and mining). This is followed by countries with large tropical and equatorial rainforests, such as Indonesia, Brazil, and Gabon, where investments are driving deforestation for monoculture agriculture, livestock farming, and mining. (images 2, 3)

data.title: PAN ASIA-PACIFIC (PANAP)
data.desc:
PAN Asia Pacific (PANAP) is a regional network based in Malaysia, part of the global Pesticide Action Network movement. It focuses on environmental justice, food sovereignty, and human rights, particularly in the defense of rural communities, farmers, and agricultural workers in Asia and the Pacific.

NO LAND, NO LIFE:
"No Land, No Life!" is a PAN Asia Pacific campaign denouncing land and resource grabbing in the Asia-Pacific region.
It supports the rights of farmers, indigenous peoples, and rural communities by documenting land-related violence and conflict, and promoting agrarian reform and food sovereignty through monitoring, training, and international mobilization.

data.title: VIOLENCE AGAINST LAND OCCUPATION AND LAND TENOR (CPT)
data.desc:
The Pastoral Land Commission (CPT) is an organization of the Brazilian Catholic Church, founded in 1975 to defend peasants, landless people, and indigenous peoples. It denounces violence and agrarian injustice, promotes land reform, and collects data on rural conflicts in Brazil, becoming one of the main reference sources on these issues.

The article presents an overview of partial data (January-August 2021) collected by the Pastoral Land Commission (CPT) on rural conflicts in Brazil, highlighting a sharp increase in violence over land occupation and ownership. 418 territories were recorded as affected, with marked increases in “home destruction,” “expropriation,” “expulsion,” and “land grabbing.” Deaths “due to conflict” rose from 9 (2020) to 103 (2021), of which 101 were indigenous Yanomami. Of the 26 homicides linked to rural conflicts, 6 were landless workers (5 in the state of Rondônia) and 3 were quilombolas in Maranhão. The article also denounces the invasion of Yanomami territories by illegal miners, with acts of violence, water contamination, disease, environmental destruction, and cases of children “swept up in dredges.”

data.title: LARGEST REPOSSESSION OPERATION IN RONDONIA REPETS THE TRACES OF THE CORUMBIARA MASSACRE
data.desc: In November 2021, in the state of Rondônia, 300 landless families were forcibly evicted from the NorBrasil and Arco-Íris farms, in an operation conducted by military police and the National Force. The lands were claimed by the company Leme Empreendimentos Ltda., accused of illegal appropriation. The eviction resulted in serious human rights violations, with homes and documents destroyed and two farmers killed. According to the CPT, the lands were either public or illegally acquired.

data.title: GLOBAL WITNESS KILLINGS REPORT (2012-2024)
data.desc: 2,253 land and environmental defenders were killed or disappeared between 2012 and 2024

data.title: DECLERATION OF TIRANA
data.desc:
FIRST TIME LAND GRABBING IS RECOGNIZED AND CONDEMNED:
We denounce all forms of land grabbing, both international and national.
We denounce local land grabs by powerful local elites, within the community, or among
family members. We denounce large-scale land grabbing, which has accelerated dramatically
over the past three years and which we define as an acquisition or concession with one or more of the
following characteristics:

(I) is in violation of human rights, particularly women's equal rights; (II) is not based on the free, prior, and informed
consent of affected land users; (III) is not based on, or fails to take into account, a comprehensive assessment of
social, economic, and environmental impacts, including how gender aspects are addressed;
(IV) is not based on transparent contracts specifying commitments regarding activities, work, and benefit-sharing;
(V) is not based on effective democratic planning, independent oversight, and meaningful participation.

data.title: WHAT IF HOMES BECOME TRAPS FOR RESIDENTS?
data.desc:
SCENARIO:
In the near future, a private enterprise is ushering in the latest stage of touristification: private housing as an attraction. The enterprise offers residents the opportunity to stay in the city center for free, provided they live in showcase apartments designed for the tourist experience.
Visitors purchase a ticket to observe the daily lives of the residents, with the option of requesting personalized performances for a fee. Reviews and interactions determine residents' extra earnings, while a curated catalog allows tourists to choose the human profile they want to "visit."

CONFLICT:
A conflict arises between residents and urban infrastructure as homes become tourist attractions. Driven by the economic interests of private companies and urban policies, homes lose their intimate function, transforming into exposed and controlled spaces for the benefit of tourists.

WHO:
A private company, following its success in the tourist resort sector, is launching a new project: glass condominiums in the city center.
The aim is to pioneer a new market, offering residents the opportunity to live for free in the city center, provided they disclose their daily routines.
Tourists pay a fee and are provided with a kit for their reserved time slot.

OUTPUT:
Users can identify with tourists by receiving the app and the kit with the watch that marks the visit slot, or with residents by wearing the collar that unlocks only when all tourists have finished their visits and given the OK from their watch.

data.title: WHAT IF INFRASTRUCTURES WERE BUILT BY RECYCLING THE GOODS, MEMORIES, AND BLOOD OF THE OPPRESSED?
data.desc:
SCENARIO:
In the near future, a major construction company is entering the market with an innovative and cost-effective solution: building large-scale infrastructure with materials and resources recovered from occupied territories. The company manages everything from land acquisition to infrastructure construction.

CONFLICT:
The conflict pits local communities and investors against each other over the appropriation of land and its contents under the guise of "public need." This dynamic causes casualties, which are then reused for infrastructure construction.

WHO:
The agency is a construction company that serves large multi-utility companies, taking on the construction of strategic infrastructure such as dams, power plants, and railways. It carefully describes its materials, demonstrating their suitability based on parameters such as price, provenance, and efficiency.

OUTPUT:
Users can assume the role of customers.
They are provided with a machine that shows whether or not it's worth building in a given location, based on the availability and quality of resources; and a sample of usable materials, which can be examined under a microscope for a detailed analysis of each element's composition.

data.title: HUMAN RIGHTS DAY 2019: LAND RELATED KILLINGS GO UP (PANAP)
data.desc:
According to the PAN Asia Pacific (PANAP) report of December 10, 2019, land conflict-related killings have been attributed to various actors, including:
Paramilitary groups and private security forces: often associated with economic interests, such as agribusiness and mining.
State armed forces
Non-state armed groups: Some conflicts involve armed groups fighting for control of land and resources.
These actors often act with impunity, facilitated by weak laws and a lack of accountability. The primary victims are farmers, community leaders, and land rights activists, especially in countries such as Colombia, the Philippines, and Mexico.
PANAP emphasizes the need for independent investigations and greater protection for rural communities threatened by these conflicts.

data.title: LAND AND RIGHT WATHC - 2022 REPORT (PANAP)
data.desc:
The report monitors human rights violations suffered by communities resisting land and resource grabbing in the Asia-Pacific.

Biofuels despite being promoted as an alternative to fossil fuels, have caused deforestation, land degradation, and human rights violations. PANAP has monitored over 1.3 million hectares affected by biofuels and land conflicts. A case in point is San Mariano (Philippines), where Green Future Innovations Inc. expropriated peasant lands to grow sugarcane, causing environmental degradation, pollution, respiratory diseases, and threats to farmers, who have lost income and security.

Large-scale renewable energy projects, such as dams, wind turbines, and solar farms, have caused forced displacement and environmental damage. Examples include the Lower Sesan 2 dam in Cambodia, which has displaced up to 5,000 people; the K Rail project in India risks displacing 20,000 families. PANAP estimates that renewable infrastructure requires approximately 300,000 hectares of land, resulting in the loss of homes and livelihoods.

data.title: REPRESSION FOR LAND AND PROFITS - OCTOBER 2022 (PANAP)
data.desc:
Data from PAN Asia Pacific (PANAP) shows that every week, over the past five years, at least two people in rural communities have been killed in conflicts over land grabbing.
It also claims that repression, land speculation, and violence are being used to protect corporate profits and interests at the expense of farmers.
Specific cases cited: Agbede (Nigeria), Edelira (Paraguay), Hacienda Tinang (Philippines)

data.title: GLOBAL WITNESS 2021 LAS LINE DEFENSE REPORT ANALYSIS
data.desc:
NUMBER OF CASES AND VICTIMS OF HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS RELATED TO LAND CONFLICTS AND STRUGGLES, FROM JANUARY 1, 2017 TO JULY 31, 2025
Global Witness is an investigative and activist organization that has been working for over 30 years to expose the links between environmental destruction, conflict, corruption, and human rights violations.
The organization investigates how industries fueling the climate crisis profit from destruction and supports people fighting to defend their communities and their rights.

A GLOBAL ANALYSIS
ATTACKS ON THE RISE FOR ANOTHER YEAR

In 2020, Global Witness recorded 227 murdered land and environmental defenders – making it once again the most dangerous year on record for people defending their homes, land and livelihoods. However, our data on killings does not capture the true scale of the problem. In some countries, the situation facing defenders is hard to gauge – restrictions on a free press, or where the independent monitoring of attacks on defenders is not taking place, can lead to underreporting. Land disputes and environmental damage, two of the prominent underlying causes behind communities’ activism, can also be difficult to monitor in parts of the world  affected by conflict.
We know that beyond killings, many defenders and communities also experience attempts to silence them, with tactics like death threats, surveillance, sexual violence, or criminalisation – and that these
kinds of attacks are even less well reported. These challenges, coupled with the requirement to meet strict verification criteria for recording killings, mean that our figures are almost certainly an underestimate.

HIGHEST COUNTRIES PER CAPITA
1. Nicaragua
2. Honduras
3. Colombia
4. Guatemala
5. Philippines

data.title: IS LAND GRABBING LEGAL?
data.desc:
It must be stated immediately that this practice is not a crime: the type of litigation initiated cannot be assimilated to a criminal proceeding, but rather to a civil offense.

Land occupation generally finds its legal basis in perfectly valid and lawful acts, because they comply with national laws. However, this occupation, while valid, can be substantially unjust and violate other laws (such as those protecting the fundamental rights to food and water, or to housing, or to the identity and culture of an indigenous people) because very often the legal framework justifying it does not respect all the rights at stake.

Since militarily occupying a country is no longer accepted, it is better to occupy it 'economically.' And even better if we can legally extract the resources.

An indigenous community that occupies land collectively (and this is the typical way many indigenous communities manage spaces) or that has occupied it for centuries, almost never has the opportunity to demonstrate to have a property title. Also because the very concept of "property" is often unknown in these cultures, where the land belongs to everyone."

data.title: GAZA STRIP CASE STUDY
data.desc:
Approximately 82% of the Gaza Strip is currently occupied by Israeli forces, and 60%* of Palestinian land is expected to remain under Israeli control.

*(Beit Lahiya, Beit Hanoon, some Gaza neighborhoods (Shujayea, Tuffah, Zeitoun), more than half of Khan Younis, and virtually all of Rafah).
Impact on Palestinian Displacement
The continued Israeli presence in these key areas makes it unlikely that hundreds of thousands of displaced Palestinians will return to their homes in the short term, despite the ceasefire.

Israel's planning system, which is used as a legal pretext for demolitions, is described as fundamentally discriminatory, making building permits "nearly impossible for Palestinians to obtain."

As of October 2023, none of the 282 applications submitted have been approved.

data.title: HOW DOES A CONSTRUCTION COMPANY WORK?
data.desc:
A construction company is an organization or firm that deals with the construction, renovation, maintenance, and demolition of buildings or other physical structures such as bridges and roads.
It may be involved in various phases of the construction process, from planning and design to actual construction and post-construction management.

data.title: ADRIANA VAREJAO: ART TO DENOUNCE LAND GRABBING
data.desc:
Adriana Varejão (born in Rio de Janeiro in 1964) is a contemporary Brazilian artist known for her multidisciplinary work exploring themes of colonialism, anthropology, and cultural syncretism. She uses painting, sculpture, photography, and installation, with a particular focus on azulejo (Portuguese tile), which she uses to reflect on Brazilian history and identity. Her works are included in the collections of major international museums.

THE MESSAGE:
Beneath the outer and rational surface of the infrastructure lies a primordial, physical, and often violent reality.The building hides secrets and bears the marks of history and suffering.

data.title: WHAT IS THE LINK BETWEEN BODIES AND INFRASTRUCTURE?
data.desc:
THE CARYATIDS AND THE ATLASES/TELAMONS:
The human body, in an idealized and sometimes heroic form, is elevated to the role of a fundamental pillar of sacred architecture. (Image 1)

GARGOYLE:
Its function is primarily aesthetic and serves as a warning against evil or sin for the faithful, but it also serves to ward off evil spirits from the sacred building. (image 2)

VITRUVIAN MANAND CORBUSIAN MODULOR:
The body has also been used as a canon and unit of measurement for space. (image 3)

BONES AS A DECORATIVE ELEMENT:
The remains of bodies after death have been used in various cultures as an aesthetic and symbolic element.

USING INFRASTRUCTURES AS CULTURAL DOMINATION:
In many American construction sites, it was necessary to deface sacred Native American burial sites.

data.title: TYPES OF CONSTRUCTION COMPANIES
data.desc:
General contractors:
They handle complete construction projects, managing all aspects of the construction process, from foundation to roof.
They often subcontract specific parts of the work to specialized contractors.
Specialized construction contractors:
Focus on specific niches in the construction industry, such as electrical, plumbing, carpentry, masonry, etc.
They can work as subcontractors for general construction contractors or directly for the client.
Renovation contractors:
Specialize in the renovation, restoration, and renovation of existing buildings.
They can work on residential, commercial, or historic projects.
Residential construction companies:
Focused on residential construction, including single-family homes, condominiums, villas, etc.
They can develop large-scale projects or build on a one-off basis.
Commercial construction companies:
Specialized in buildings and structures for commercial use, such as offices, shops, hotels, and industrial complexes.
Civil and infrastructure engineering companies:
Focused on large infrastructure projects such as bridges, roads, dams, and other civil engineering works.
Public sector construction companies:
Work on projects commissioned by public entities, such as schools, hospitals, and public infrastructure.
Demolition and remediation companies:
Specialized in building demolition and site remediation, often as a preparatory step for new construction projects.

data.title: HOW TO START A BUSINESS
data.desc:
Legal and bureaucratic requirements for starting a construction business:
Choice of legal form: Determine whether the business will operate as a sole proprietorship, limited liability company (LLC), joint stock company (SPA), etc. This choice will influence subsequent requirements.
Business registration: Register the business with the local Chamber of Commerce, obtaining a registration number and VAT number.
Registration in the register of artisan businesses (if applicable): If the business qualifies as an artisan business, it is necessary to register with the Chamber of Commerce.
Professional qualification requirements: The owner or a technical manager of the business must meet specific professional requirements, which may include degrees in engineering, architecture, or proven experience in the construction sector.
Specific certifications and permits: Depending on the type of construction work you intend to undertake, specific certifications and permits may be required. For example, work involving work on load-bearing structures requires specific skills and certifications.
Insurance policies: Specific insurance policies are required to cover professional risks, damage to third parties, and possible workplace injuries.
Occupational safety: Comply with all occupational health and safety requirements, including appointing a safety manager and employee training.
Tax and accounting management: Establish adequate accounting management, including invoicing, accounting records, and tax compliance.

data.title: JOB TITLES
data.desc:
Construction contractor or business owner:
Skills: Strategic vision, knowledge of the construction industry, entrepreneurial skills.
Experience: Often requires years of experience in the construction industry or specific training in civil engineering or architecture.
Technical manager or project manager:
Skills: In-depth knowledge of construction techniques, building regulations, and project management.
Experience: Training in civil engineering, architecture, or equivalent, as well as relevant experience, is required.
Surveyor or construction technician:
Skills: Ability to read technical drawings, plan, and supervise construction site work.
Experience: Technical training as a surveyor or equivalent.
Specialized workers (bricklayers, carpenters, plumbers, electricians):
Skills: Specific skills in their field of specialization, knowledge of safety regulations.
Experience: Specific professional training and, often, practical experience in the sector.
Safety officers:
Skills: Knowledge of workplace safety regulations, ability to implement safety protocols.
Experience: specific training in workplace safety.
Administrative Staff:
Skills: Administrative management, accounting, human resources management.
Experience: Training in administration or accounting.
Procurement Manager:
Skills: Ability to negotiate and manage supplies and contracts.
Experience: Knowledge of the building materials market and procurement practices.
Support Staff (warehouse workers, drivers, etc.):
Skills: Specific skills related to their role, such as warehouse management or driving heavy vehicles.
Experience: Specific training or certifications (e.g., driver's license) are often required.
External Consultants (Engineers, Architects, Lawyers):
Skills: Technical or legal expertise required for complex projects or to manage legal matters.
Experience: Highly specialized and trained in their specific field.

data.title: HISTORY
data.desc:
Origins and Antiquity
Early Civilizations: Construction arose from the human need to create safe, controlled environments to protect against the elements. In Mesopotamian and Egyptian civilizations, local materials such as mud and stone were used to build monumental structures, such as temples and pyramids.
Greece and Rome: These civilizations introduced technical innovations and concepts of harmonious proportion. The Romans, in particular, developed advanced techniques such as the construction of vaults and domes, creating imposing buildings such as the Colosseum.
Middle Ages and Renaissance

Middle Ages: Medieval construction saw a regression in techniques, with simpler yet more majestic constructions such as castles and cathedrals.
Renaissance: Classical Greco-Roman architecture was rediscovered. Figures such as Brunelleschi and Alberti promoted the design of symmetrical and elegant buildings.
The Industrial Age and the 20th Century
Industrial Revolution: The introduction of new materials such as steel and reinforced concrete revolutionized construction possibilities, leading to the construction of innovative skyscrapers and bridges.
Regulation in Italy: At the beginning of the 20th century, the lack of regulations led to uneven construction and an irrational use of land. The fundamental law of 1942 introduced urban planning tools (such as the master plan) and the requirement for building permits in major urban centers. The subsequent "bridge law" of 1967 extended the requirement for building permits to the entire country.

data.title: HUMAN MATERIALS IN BUILDING / BODY AS MATERIAL
data.desc:
Blood: 
Rare but attested in medieval and Renaissance sources. It was sometimes used in small quantities in mortars or pigments, similar to animal blood.
It was believed to improve the cohesion and adhesion of materials or to have apotropaic (magical-protective) value.
Historical examples:
Some late medieval chronicles describe human or animal blood being added to the mortar of defensive walls or foundations "to give strength to the construction."
In some ritual cases, the use of human blood was symbolic or mythical, not technical (e.g., "walls consecrated with the blood of prisoners").
Technical value: Similar to animal blood (rich in coagulant proteins), but exceptionally used for obvious ethical and practical reasons.

Hair: 
Fibrous reinforcement for mortars, plasters, and plasters.
Use: Mixed with lime, gypsum, or clay to prevent cracking. From the Renaissance to the 19th century in Europe. Usually sourced from barber shops or household scraps.
Common alternative: horsehair or ox hair, which are longer and more durable.

Bones and Teeth:
Burnt human bones (rich in phosphates and carbonates) were sometimes ground to obtain limestone powders or white pigments (bone white).
Bone ash could be used in some mortars or ceramic glazes.
Dissemination: Limited, but well documented in the decorative arts and primitive cements.

Urine:
It contained ammonia and urea, therefore used as a cleaner, degreaser, or alkaline additive.
In construction, it was used to prepare pigments, treat metal surfaces, or soften lime.
Examples:
In ancient Rome, urine was collected in fullonicae (laundries) for the processing of fabrics, but it was also used to clean marble surfaces and frescoes.
In some medieval contexts, it was mixed with lime or earth to increase plasticity.

Other secondary human organic materials:
Sweat and fat:
Traces present in hand-mixed clays, but not intentional additives.
Ash from human remains: 
In rare ritual cases, used symbolically for plaster or commemorative decorations.
Placenta or birth blood: 
Mentioned only in magico-ritual texts or building folklore (not as an actual building practice).

data.title: EXPERIMENTAL STUDY ON CONCRETE REINFORCED WITH HUMAN AND HORSE HAIR FIBERS
data.desc: Concrete is good in compression but week in tension that is, concrete is a brittle material. So, in order to improve the tensile properties of concrete, short fibers are used. Human and horse hairs consider a bio material and have a good strong in tension; hence it can be used as a fiber reinforcement material. Hair Fiber (HE) an alternate non-degradable matter is available in abundance and at a very cheap cost. Iti also creates environmental problem for its decompositions. The aim of this research work is to find out the propertiles (mechanical) of hair fiber reinforced concrete. Experiments were conducted on concrete cylinders, cubes and prisms with various percentages of human and horse hairs fibers i.e. 0%, 19%, 1.5%, and 2.5 % by weight of cement. Two grades of reference plain concrete were used, 20 and 40 MPa: The results showed that there is an increment in the various mechanical properties and strength of concrete by addition of human and horse hairs to concrete.

data.title: EVALUATION OF THE BINDING EFFECT OF HUMAN SERUM ALBUMIN ON THE PROPERTIES OF GRANULES
data.desc: The main objective of this study was the application of a solution of human serum albumin as a granulating fluid. The properties of the granules formed were evaluated and compared with those when a conventional binder was applied in the same concentration. The powder mixture contained a soluble (mannitol) and an insoluble component (different types of cellulose). The protein solution applied exerted an appropriate aggregating effect if the system contained microcrystalline celluloses. Powdered cellulose was not suitable for the granulation with human serum albumin solution. As compared with the same concentration of the conventionally applied cellulose ethers as binder, the prepared granules exhibited a larger particle size, a significantly better compressibility, a higher breaking hardness and a favourable deformation process. These findings mainly reflect the good adhesive properties of the protein. The best compressibility and mechanical behaviour were attained on the application of the microcrystaline cellulose Vivapur type 105. This favourable behaviour may be connected with the wettability of cellulose. These results suggest that the formulation of tablets may be easier from an active agent in the serum that binds to albumin (le.g. interferon) since the amount of additives (binder) can be reduced.

data.title: SUSTAINABLE COMPOSITE DEVELOPMENT: NOVEL USE OF HUMAN HAIR AS A FIBER IN CONCRETE
ASTROCRETE
data.desc:
Astrocrete:
An extension of the Lunarcrete idea is AstroCrete, which proposes using human serum albumin (HSA) as a binder, mixed with regolith.
In experiments, HSA + regolith composites have achieved compressive strengths in the order of ~25 MPa, and by adding urea (derived from urine, sweat, and tears), the strength can reach ~40 MPa.

The idea is that astronauts themselves could produce albumin, which would be used as a "glue" to build structures on the lunar or Martian soil: "stone from blood."

It has also been estimated that with a crew of six people, hundreds of kilograms of AstroCrete could be produced in two years, contributing to the expansion of interplanetary habitats.

data.title: WHAT KIND OF COMPANY ARE WE?
data.desc:
It's easier to focus on a single aspect (e.g., the production of building materials). We could say we're a 'multi-brand' company; there are several departments, and we could be a branch of this multi-brand. But if we position ourselves as the first, we can't already be a multinational → let's focus on the bodies and materials.

A company that wants to build a dam comes to us only for the materials; for the construction, it turns to someone else.

→ Building materials supplier?

We could rely on a demolition company, which demolitions and supplies us with materials. But we could do the same: we demolish and produce materials to build new infrastructure.
Let's also think about the type of output that could be achieved: who are our clients? Other large companies and their clients?
The client chooses the characteristics of the materials and puts them in a specification, and then the company goes to the supplier, who supplies them.
We basically have a stock of bodies.
But being a construction materials company gives us less room for maneuver regarding output. Also because demolition is a very important part of our business (which, however, belongs to the construction company).

Over 16,000 customers have enjoyed the services offered by Eco Green with satisfaction and punctuality. With 24 vehicles and over 500 roll-off containers for debris and waste, the company ensures professionalism and expertise for each client.

Industrial Waste and Debris Collection, Sorting, and Management Plant
Our plant specializes in the sustainable management of industrial waste and debris, offering efficient solutions for the recovery and reuse of materials. Thanks to advanced technologies and a structured process, we ensure maximum compliance with environmental regulations and reduced ecological impact.
Process Phases

1. Collection and Delivery
Material from construction sites, demolitions, and industrial activities is delivered to our plant using authorized vehicles and in compliance with current regulations.
2. Sorting and Selection
Waste is subjected to a mechanical and manual sorting process to separate recyclable materials (concrete, bricks, metals, wood, plastic, glass) from non-reusable materials.
3. Processing and Optimization
a. The debris and bricks are sent to dedicated shredding plants and quarries for recovery and reuse in the construction sector.
b. Waste such as plastic is shredded to facilitate recycling and transformation into new raw materials.
c. Our plant also has a press that compresses waste, optimizing transportation and reducing logistics costs and environmental impact.
4. Disposal and Recovery
Non-recoverable waste is disposed of in authorized facilities, ensuring maximum environmental safety. The recovered material is reintroduced into the production cycle, contributing to the circular economy.
5. Benefits and Sustainability
Reduced environmental impact thanks to the recovery of inert materials
Regulatory compliance and guaranteed traceability of managed waste
Efficiency and optimization of disposal and recycling processes
Technical support and consulting for waste management on construction sites

data.title: HOW ARE MATERIALS MANAGED TODAY?
data.desc:
Material selection in construction projects involves three main actors: the client, the contractor, and the supplier, each with distinct responsibilities. The client, together with the designer and site supervisor, defines the project requirements in terms of performance, aesthetics, budget, durability, and regulatory compliance. These are translated by the designer into technical specifications within the Project Specification (Capitolato). For certain materials, especially finishes or visible elements, the client may approve samples or technical data sheets before purchase.

The contractor is responsible for selecting and procuring materials that meet the specified requirements. This includes assessing feasibility, optimizing costs and delivery times, managing purchasing and logistics, and ensuring that materials delivered to the site comply with the specifications. Together with the site supervisor, the contractor checks certifications and test reports to verify material conformity.

The supplier proposes materials that meet the project’s technical and regulatory criteria, offering technical support and ensuring quality. They provide all necessary documentation—such as CE marking and certificates of conformity—and guarantee timely delivery to the construction site.


→ Client/Designer defines WHAT is needed (technical and aesthetic requirements, budget) = specifications.

→ Company searches the market for WHO can provide that WHAT at the best price/service (selects suppliers) = quotes, orders.

→ Supplier offers the WHAT and guarantees its quality = delivery with certifications.

→ Project Manager/Company verifies on site that the materials are actually those agreed upon.

data.title: CONCEPT
data.desc:
ALCHEMY

Alchemy is an esoteric philosophical system that since ancient times, through various disciplines, has aimed to achieve the highest level of knowledge, spiritual perfection, and the search for the Philosopher's Stone through the transformation of matter.
The term alchemy derives from the Arabic l-khīmiyya or al-kīmiyya, composed of the definite article al- and the word kīmiyya, meaning "chemistry," which in turn appears to descend from the Greek term khymeia (χυμεία), meaning "to melt," "to pour together," "to weld," "to attach."
Alchemy is an esoteric science whose primary goal was to transform lead, or the negative, into gold, or the positive in man.

data.title: IS THE THEME OF LANDGRABBING FUNCTIONAL TO THIS REFLECTION?
data.desc:
Is it plausible that we legalize killing people?
In our scenario, the stock part doesn't work because it loses its meaning. (It makes no sense to build an infrastructure in Brazil with the Chinese bodies.)

In war, it's legal to kill if the targets are military (i.e., military bases, tanks, soldiers, etc.).
It's not legal to kill civilians → War crime

Why can't we legalize killing people in land grabbing too? Make it legal to kill local targets (i.e., people who live there and occupy the space, their homes, etc.).

Why isn't it plausible? Why is it okay for soldiers but not for civilians?
-> Because it's a legacy + a necessity: you kill to protect yourself as a state, so it's okay.

Until the 20th century, it was okay to kill to expand the state and its population.

Another reason why it's not plausible: we are a predominantly moralistic society. (You can't kill regardless.)
With this scenario, we focus on Utilitarianism: 
Social gain - loss of lives > 0

Current examples of "utilitarian laws":
- Death penalty → you sacrifice a person's life for the "common good"
- Covid → you sacrifice individual freedoms for the "common good"
- QUALY → you sacrifice the care of some because the care can make others live longer

CONCLUSION:
I CANNOT BUILD A BUSINESS OUT OF THIS BECAUSE, ALTHOUGH LANDGRABBING IS NOT ILLEGAL, KILLING PEOPLE IS: SO PEOPLE DIE, BUT WE'RE NOT 'AUTHORIZED' TO USE THEIR BODIES

data.title: LET'S MAKE THE LANDGRABBING SCENARIO PLAUSIBLE
data.desc:
In the near future, the legal ambiguity surrounding land grabbing will be clarified:
Land grabbing is fully legal, with all that this entails, given the "public need."
If the local population disagrees, they can attack/oppose the eviction in some way.
Multinational X can open fire on the local population if it is done in self-defense.
In the conflict, victims become raw materials for our company and material for future infrastructure.

Our problem is that deaths aren't certain: we need to make them certain.

→ What if land grabbing became the solution to overpopulation?

We don't kill people. Someone else does land grabbing and kills people.

data.title: WHAT IF OUR SCENARIO INVOLVES A COMPANY USING DEAD BODIES AS CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS FOR INFRASTRUCTURE?
data.desc:
We want to consider all deaths related to infrastructure in general (e.g., workplace deaths, such as those at a stadium in Qatar, or a road in Russia, including land grabbing)?

Land grabbing is too broad; it doesn't just affect infrastructure. 
-> But the general theme of infrastructure conflict might be too narrow: what would the conflict be? Who are the specific actors?

OUR GENERAL THEME is that there's a hidden underlying violence behind the construction of infrastructure.
We want to consider the deaths before and during construction.

Let's consider all deaths due to a violent act: deaths from land grabbing, workplace deaths (generally when there's insufficient protection from the organization).
→ The conflict is between the victims (all the victims we'll analyze with our case studies) and the organizations that want to build the infrastructure.
We can "take care" of every death in construction workplace.

data.title: THREE GORGES DAM (CHINA)
data.desc: The case of the Three Gorges Dam in China, while not typical of land grabbing by multinational agricultural companies, represents a colossal example of state land grabbing for the construction of a large-scale infrastructure project, with comparable social consequences. The creation of the gigantic hydroelectric reservoir on the Yangtze River required the expropriation of over 1,300,000 people – the largest forced displacement in history – who were forced to abandon their homes, their agricultural lands, entire cities, and priceless archaeological sites, with massive long-term social and economic impacts, despite the relocation programs implemented by the Chinese government. The project is therefore an emblematic case of "expropriation for public utility" on an epochal scale, which has radically and irreversibly altered the ecological and demographic balance of an entire region for energy and flood control purposes.

data.title: THE SIAT LAND GRABBING CASE IN IVORY COAST
data.desc: The land grabbing case involving SIAT (Société d'Investissement pour l'Agriculture Tropicale) in Côte d'Ivoire is a controversy surrounding the grabbing of vast swathes of land by the Belgian company, specializing in rubber and palm oil production, to the detriment of local and indigenous communities. SIAT is accused of acquiring the land to expand its plantations in a process that, according to complaints from NGOs and affected populations (including in Ghana and Nigeria), was conducted without due consultation or fair compensation. The consequences of this "land theft" include the loss of agricultural land vital to communities' livelihoods and food security, human rights violations, forced displacement, and severe environmental degradation due to intensive monocultures. Local communities, supported by organizations such as CIDSE and Focsiv, have forcefully demanded the restitution of their plots, compensation for the damages suffered, and the implementation of a transparent, rights-based dialogue process.
